section.title: DROP FUNCTION Statement
section.para: The DROP FUNCTION statement removes a user-defined function (UDF) from the Trafodion database.

note.para: DDL statements are not currently supported in transactions. That means that you cannot run this statement inside a user-defined transaction (BEGIN WORK...COMMIT WORK) or when AUTOCOMMIT is OFF. To run this statement, AUTOCOMMIT must be turned ON (the default) for the session.

entry.programlisting: DROP FUNCTION [[catalog-name.]schema-name.]function-name [RESTRICT | CASCADE]

listitem.para: specifies the ANSI logical name of the function, where each part of the name is a valid SQL identifier with a maximum of 128 characters. Specify the name of a function that has already been registered in the schema. If you do not fully qualify the function name, Trafodion SQL qualifies it according to the schema of the current session. For more information, see and .
If you specify RESTRICT, the DROP FUNCTION operation fails if the function is used in a trigger.
If you specify CASCADE, both the function and any triggers that use the function are dropped during the DROP FUNCTION operation.
The default value is RESTRICT.
RESTRICT requires that all triggers that use the function be dropped before you drop the function. CASCADE automatically drops any triggers that are using the function.

section.title: Required Privileges
section.para: To issue a DROP FUNCTION statement, one of the following must be true:

listitem.para: You are DB__ROOT.
You are the owner of the function.
You have the DROP or DROP_ROUTINE component privilege for SQL_OPERATIONS component.
This DROP FUNCTION statement removes the function named ADD2 from the default schema:
listitem.programlisting: DROP FUNCTION add2;

listitem.para: This DROP FUNCTION statement removes the function named MMA5 from the default schema:
listitem.programlisting: DROP PROCEDURE mma5;

listitem.para: This DROP FUNCTION statement removes the function named REVERSE from the default schema:
listitem.programlisting: DROP PROCEDURE reverse;

section.title: DROP INDEX Statement
section.para: The DROP INDEX statement drops a Trafodion SQL index. See .
DROP INDEX is a Trafodion SQL extension.

note.para: DDL statements are not currently supported in transactions. That means that you cannot run this statement inside a user-defined transaction (BEGIN WORK...COMMIT WORK) or when AUTOCOMMIT is OFF. To run this statement, AUTOCOMMIT must be turned ON (the default) for the session.

entry.programlisting: DROP [VOLATILE] INDEX index

listitem.para: is the index to drop.
For information, see .

section.title: Required Privileges
section.para: To issue a DROP INDEX statement, one of the following must be true:

listitem.para: You are DB__ROOT.
You are the owner of the index or the table associated with the index.
You have the DROP or DROP_INDEX component privilege for the SQL_OPERATIONS component.
This example drops an index:
listitem.programlisting: DROP INDEX myindex;

listitem.para: This example drops a volatile index:
listitem.programlisting: DROP VOLATILE INDEX vindex;

section.title: DROP LIBRARY Statement
section.para: The DROP LIBRARY statement removes a library object from the Trafodion database and also removes the library file referenced by the library object.
DROP LIBRARY is a Trafodion SQL extension.

note.para: DDL statements are not currently supported in transactions. That means that you cannot run this statement inside a user-defined transaction (BEGIN WORK...COMMIT WORK) or when AUTOCOMMIT is OFF. To run this statement, AUTOCOMMIT must be turned ON (the default) for the session.

entry.programlisting: DROP LIBRARY [[catalog-name.]schema-name.]library-name [RESTRICT | CASCADE]

listitem.para: specifies the ANSI logical name of the library object, where each part of the name is a valid SQL identifier with a maximum of 128 characters. Specify the name of a library object that has already been registered in the schema. If you do not fully qualify the library name, Trafodion SQL qualifies it according to the schema of the current session. For more information, see and .
If you specify RESTRICT, the DROP LIBRARY operation fails if any stored procedures in Java (SPJs) or user-defined functions (UDFs) were created based on the specified library.
If you specify CASCADE, any such dependent procedures or functions are removed as part of the DROP LIBRARY operation.
The default value is RESTRICT.

RESTRICT requires that all procedures and functions that refer to the library object be dropped before you drop the library object. CASCADE automatically drops any procedures or functions that are using the library.
If the library filename referenced by the library object does not exist, Trafodion SQL issues a warning.

section.title: Required Privileges
section.para: To issue a DROP LIBRARY statement, one of the following must be true:

listitem.para: You are DB__ROOT.
You are the owner of the library.
You have the DROP or DROP_LIBRARY component privilege for the SQL_OPERATIONS component.

This DROP LIBRARY statement removes the library named SALESLIB from the SALES schema, removes the Sales2.jar file referenced by the library, and drops any stored procedures in Java (SPJs) that were created based on this library:
listitem.programlisting: DROP LIBRARY sales.saleslib CASCADE;

listitem.para: This DROP LIBRARY statement removes the library named MYUDFS from the default schema and removes the $TMUDFS library file referenced by the library:
listitem.programlisting: DROP LIBRARY myudfs RESTRICT;
listitem.para: RESTRICT prevents the DROP LIBRARY operation from dropping any user-defined functions (UDFs) that were created based on this library. If any UDFs were created based on this library, the DROP LIBRARY operation fails.

section.title: DROP PROCEDURE Statement
section.para: The DROP PROCEDURE statement removes a stored procedure in Java (SPJ) from the Trafodion database.

note.para: DDL statements are not currently supported in transactions. That means that you cannot run this statement inside a user-defined transaction (BEGIN WORK...COMMIT WORK) or when AUTOCOMMIT is OFF. To run this statement, AUTOCOMMIT must be turned ON (the default) for the session.

entry.programlisting: DROP PROCEDURE [[catalog-name.]schema-name.]procedure-name [RESTRICT | CASCADE]

listitem.para: specifies the ANSI logical name of the stored procedure in Java (SPJ), where each part of the name is a valid SQL identifier with a maximum of 128 characters. Specify the name of a procedure that has already been registered in the schema. If you do not fully qualify the procedure name, Trafodion SQL qualifies it according to the schema of the current session. For more information, see and .
If you specify RESTRICT, the DROP PROCEDURE operation fails if the procedure is used in a trigger.
If you specify CASCADE, both the procedure and any triggers that use the procedure are dropped during the DROP PROCEDURE operation.
The default value is RESTRICT.
RESTRICT requires that all triggers that use the procedure be dropped before you drop the procedure. CASCADE automatically drops any triggers that are using the procedure.

section.title: Required Privileges
section.para: To issue a DROP PROCEDURE statement, one of the following must be true:

listitem.para: You are DB__ROOT.
You are the owner of the procedure.
You have the DROP or DROP_ROUTINE component privilege for SQL_OPERATIONS component.
This DROP PROCEDURE statement removes the procedure named LOWERPRICE from the SALES schema:
listitem.programlisting: DROP PROCEDURE sales.lowerprice;

listitem.para: This DROP PROCEDURE statement removes the procedure TOTALPRICE from the default schema for the session, which is the SALES schema:
listitem.programlisting: SET SCHEMA sales; DROP PROCEDURE totalprice;

section.title: DROP ROLE Statement
section.para: The DROP ROLE statement deletes an SQL role. See .

entry.programlisting: DROP ROLE role-name

listitem.para:
is an existing role name. The role cannot be dropped if any of the following are true:
Any privileges are granted to the role.
The role is granted to any users.
The role owns any schemas.

To drop a role, you must own the role or have user administrative privileges for the role. You have user administrative privileges for the role if you have been granted the MANAGE_ROLES component privilege. Initially, DB__ROOT is the only database user who has been granted the MANAGE_ROLES component privilege.
Role names beginning with DB__ are reserved and can only be dropped by DB__ROOT.
You can determine all users to whom a role has been granted by using the SHOWDDL ROLE statement. See the .

section.title: Before You Drop a Role
section.para: Before dropping a role, follow these guidelines:

listitem.para: You must revoke all privileges granted to the role.
You must revoke the role from all users to whom it was granted.
You must drop all schemas the role is a manager (or owner) of.

section.para: You can determine all users to whom a role has been granted with the SHOWDDL statement. See the .

section.title: Active Sessions for the User
section.para: In Trafodion Release 0.9, when you revoke a role from a user, the effects on any active sessions for the user are undefined. We recommend that you disconnect such sessions. The user then reconnects to establish new sessions with the updated set of privileges.

Starting in Trafodion Release 1.0, when you revoke a role from a user, the change in privileges is automatically propagated to and detected by active sessions. There is no need for users to disconnect from and reconnect to a session to see the updated set of privileges.

listitem.para: To drop a role:
listitem.programlisting: DROP ROLE clerks;

entry.programlisting: DROP SCHEMA schema-name [RESTRICT|CASCADE]

If you specify CASCADE, objects in the specified schema and the schema itself are dropped. Any objects in other schemas that were dependent on objects in this schema are dropped as well.

section.title: DROP TABLE Statement
section.para: The DROP TABLE statement deletes a Trafodion SQL table and its dependent objects such as indexes and constraints. See .

note.para: DDL statements are not currently supported in transactions. That means that you cannot run this statement inside a user-defined transaction (BEGIN WORK...COMMIT WORK) or when AUTOCOMMIT is OFF. To run this statement, AUTOCOMMIT must be turned ON (the default) for the session.

entry.programlisting: DROP [VOLATILE] TABLE [IF EXISTS] table [RESTRICT|CASCADE]

listitem.para: specifies that the table to be dropped is a volatile table.
drops the HBase table if it exists. This option does not apply to volatile tables.
is the name of the table to delete.
If you specify RESTRICT and the table is referenced by another object, the specified table cannot be dropped. The default is RESTRICT.
If you specify CASCADE, the table and all objects referencing the table (such as a view) are dropped.

You have the DROP or DROP_TABLE component privilege for the SQL_OPERATIONS component.
This example drops a table:

section.title: DROP VIEW Statement
section.para: The DROP VIEW statement deletes a Trafodion SQL view. See .

entry.programlisting: DROP VIEW view [RESTRICT|CASCADE]

If you specify CASCADE, any dependent objects are dropped.

section.title: EXECUTE Statement
section.para: The EXECUTE statement executes an SQL statement previously compiled by a PREPARE statement in a Trafodion Command Interface (TrafCI) session.

entry.programlisting:
EXECUTE statement-name [ USING param [,param]...] ]
param is: ?param-name | literal-value

section.title: Syntax Description of EXECUTE

listitem.para: is the name of a prepared SQL statement—that is, the statement name used in the PREPARE statement. statement-name is an SQL identifier. See .

specifies values for unnamed parameters (represented by ?) in the prepared statement in the form of either a parameter name (?param-name) or a literal value (literal-value). The data type of a parameter value must be compatible with the data type of the associated parameter in the prepared statement.

Parameter values (param) are substituted for unnamed parameters in the prepared statement by position—the i-th value in the USING clause is the value for the i-th parameter in the statement. If fewer parameter values exist in the USING clause than unnamed parameters in the PREPARE statement, Trafodion SQL returns an error. If more parameter values exist in the USING clause than the unnamed parameters in the PREPARE statement, Trafodion SQL issues warning 15019.

The USING clause does not set parameter values for named parameters (represented by ?param‑name) in a prepared statement. To set parameter values for named parameters, use the SET PARAM commandSET PARAM command. For more information, see the Trafodion Command Interface Guide.

The value for a ?param-name must be previously specified with the SET PARAM command. The param-name is case-sensitive. For information about the SET PARAM command, see the Trafodion Command Interface Guide.
is a numeric or character literal that specifies the value for the unnamed parameter.

If literal-value is a character literal and the target column type is character, you do not have to enclose it in single quotation marks. Its data type is determined from the data type of the column to which the literal is assigned. If the literal-value contains leading or trailing spaces, commas, or if it matches any parameter names that are already set, enclose the literal-value in single quotes.

section.para: See the . For information about the SET PARAM command, see the Trafodion Command Interface Guide.

section.title: Scope of EXECUTE
section.para: A statement must be compiled by PREPARE before you EXECUTE it, but after it is compiled, you can execute the statement multiple times without recompiling it. The statement must have been compiled during the same TrafCI session as its execution.

listitem.para: Use PREPARE to compile a statement once, and then execute the statement multiple times with different parameter values. This example uses the SET PARAM command to set parameter values for named parameters (represented by ?param‑name) in the prepared statement.
listitem.programlisting:
EMPNUM FIRST_NAME LAST_NAME DEPTNUM JOBCODE SALARY ------ --------------- -------------- ------- ------- -------- 232 THOMAS SPINNER 4000 450 45000.00
--- 1 row(s) selected.

EMPNUM FIRST_NAME LAST_NAME DEPTNUM JOBCODE SALARY ------ --------------- -------------- ------- ------- -------- 75 TIM WALKER 3000 300 32000.00 89 PETER SMITH 3300 300 37000.40 ...
--- 13 row(s) selected.

listitem.para: Specify literal values in the USING clause of the EXECUTE statement for unnamed parameters in the prepared statement:
listitem.programlisting:
EMPNUM FIRST_NAME LAST_NAME DEPTNUM JOBCODE SALARY ------ --------------- -------------- ------- ------- -------- 232 THOMAS SPINNER 4000 450 45000.00
--- 1 row(s) selected.
SQL>execute findemp using 20000.00, 300;

EMPNUM FIRST_NAME LAST_NAME DEPTNUM JOBCODE SALARY ------ --------------- -------------- ------- ------- -------- 75 TIM WALKER 3000 300 32000.00 89 PETER SMITH 3300 300 37000.40 ...
--- 13 row(s) selected.

section.title: EXPLAIN Statement
section.para: The EXPLAIN statement helps you to review query execution plans. You can use the EXPLAIN statement anywhere you can execute other SQL statements (for example, SELECT). For information about TrafCI, see the Trafodion Command Interface Guide. For more information on the EXPLAIN function, see .
EXPLAIN is a Trafodion SQL extension.

entry.programlisting: EXPLAIN [OPTIONS {'f' | 'n' | 'e' | 'm'}] {FOR QID qid | query-text | prepared-stmt-name}

section.para: The syntax for the EXPLAIN statement supports four output options. summarizes the options.

row.entry: Provides the simple, basic information contained in the query execution plan. This information is formatted for readability and limited to 79 characters (one line) per operator.
Provides the most important information contained in the query execution plan. This information is formatted for readability and is the default output format.
Provides all information contained in the query execution plan. This information is formatted for readability.
Provides all information contained in the query execution plan. This information is formatted for machine readability (easy to parse with software tools). Same format as EXPLAIN function (see ).

section.para: Plans displayed by the EXPLAIN statement OPTIONS ‘n’, ‘e’, and ‘f’ are ordered from top (root operator) to bottom (leaf operators). The machine-readable format (option ‘m’) orders plans from bottom (leaf operators) to top (root operator).
For detailed information about the operators in the query execution plan, see the Trafodion Query Guide.

listitem.para: formatted. See .
normal user (default setting). See .
expert user. See .
machine readable format. See .

a delimited identifier or regular identifier, which represents the query ID. This example shows the query ID, which contains lowercase characters, as a delimited identifier:QID "MXID01001011194212103659400053369000000085905admin00_2605_S1"
a DML statement such as SELECT * FROM T3.

an SQL identifier containing the name of a statement already prepared in this session. An SQL identifier is case-insensitive (will be in uppercase) unless it is double-quoted. It must be double-quoted if it contains blanks, lowercase letters, or special characters. It must start with a letter. When you refer to the prepared query in a SELECT statement, you must use uppercase.

section.title: Required Privileges
section.para: To issue an EXPLAIN statement, one of the following must be true:

listitem.para: You are DB__ROOT.
You own (that is, issued) the query specified in the EXPLAIN statement.
You have the SHOW component privilege for the SQL_OPERATIONS component. The SHOW component privilege is granted to PUBLIC by default.

section.title: Obtaining EXPLAIN Plans While Queries Are Running
section.para: Trafodion SQL provides the ability to capture an EXPLAIN plan for a query at any time while the query is running with the FOR QID option. By default, this behavior is disabled for a Trafodion database session. To enable this feature, contact your HP Support representative for assistance.

note.para: Enable this feature before you start preparing and executing queries.

section.para: After the feature is enabled, use the FOR QID option in an EXPLAIN statement to get the query execution plan of a running query.

The EXPLAIN function or statement returns the plan that was generated when the query was prepared. EXPLAIN with the FOR QID option retrieves all the information from the original plan of the executing query. The plan is available until the query finishes executing and is removed or deallocated.

section.title: Case Considerations
section.para: In most cases, words in the commands can be in uppercase or lowercase. The options letter must be single quoted and in lowercase.

section.title: Number Considerations
section.para: Costs are given in a generic unit of effort. They show relative costs of an operation.

When numbers are displayed as 0.01 for OPTIONS ‘n’ (or 0.0001 for OPTIONS ‘e’), the numbers have likely been rounded up and are usually much smaller than shown. However, if the numbers are zero, the display shows “0”.
When trailing decimal digits are zero, they are dropped. For example, 6.4200 would display as 6.42 and 5.0 would display as 5, without a decimal point.

section.title: Formatted [OPTIONS 'f'] Considerations
section.para: The formatted option is the simplest option. It provides essential, brief information about the plan and shows the operators and their order within the query execution plan.
OPTIONS 'f' formats the EXPLAIN output into these fields:

row.entry: The sequence number of the operator in the query plan
Estimated number of rows returned by the plan. CARDINALITY and ROWS_OUT are the same.

section.para: If the query plan contains certain special tables or trigger temp tables, the DESCRIPTION field will show TT for trigger temp. This simplifies reading plans that include special tables.
This example uses OPTIONS 'f ':
section.programlisting:
>>explain options 'f' select * from region;
LC RC OP OPERATOR OPT DESCRIPTION CARD ---- ---- ---- -------------------- -------- -------------------- ---------
1 . 2 root 1.00E+002 . . 1 trafodion_scan REGION 1.00E+002
--- SQL operation complete.
section.para: To use the EXPLAIN statement with a prepared statement, first prepare the query. Then use the EXPLAIN statement:
section.programlisting:
PREPARE q FROM SELECT * FROM REGION;
EXPLAIN options 'f' q;
section.para: The FILE_SCAN operator is the only operator in this example that shows additional information in the OPT and DESCRIPTION fields. 'fs' indicates that fast-scan optimization was used. 'fr' indicates that fast-reply data-move optimization was used. The table name is shown in the DESCRIPTION field. For information about these special optimization techniques, see the listing of each operator in the Trafodion Query Guide.

section.title: Normal User [OPTIONS 'n'] Considerations
section.para: The normal user optionExplain statement OPTIONS ’n’ considerations provides more OPTIONS on Explain statement ’n’information about the query plan than OPTIONS 'f'. OPTIONS 'n' is the default option, so you can simply execute EXPLAIN query-text without specifying OPTIONS 'n'.
OPTIONS 'n' provides two digits of precision for floating-point cost values.
OPTIONS 'n' provides a plan summary and values of the fields for the operators in the query execution plan. describes the plan summary.

row.entry: Shows DYNAMICALLY COMPILED when a query statement or prepared statement is supplied as the argument to the EXPLAIN statement.
Name of the prepared statement. For example, in the prepared statement PREPARE newstmt from SELECT * FROM T, the STATEMENT_NAME field value is NEWSTMT.
An identifier generated by the database.
Estimated number of rows returned by the plan.
Estimated total cost of the plan.
SQL query being explained in this query plan.

section.para: The EXPLAIN plan outputExplain statement output provides the following information, as applicable, for each operator of the query execution plan. The "NODE LISTING" heading means a list of the plan's operators will follow.

row.entry: Current operator type, such as FILE_SCAN, HASH_JOIN, NESTED_JOIN, and so on.
Sequence number of the current operator in the query execution plan; indicates the sequence in which the query plan is generated.
Sequence number of the operator’s children (operators that feed data up to this operator). There can be 0, 1, or 2 children shown as NO CHILDREN, ONLY CHILD 6, or CHILDREN 5, 7.
Name of base table, shown only on operators that access the table.
Estimated number of requests REQUESTS_IN for execution EXPLAIN output columnsREQUESTS_IN of this operator. The value is 1 except for the right child operator (inner scan) of a nested-loop join.

Estimated number of rowsROWS_OUT ROWS/REQUEST returnedEXPLAIN output columnsROWS_OUT by the plan or, when REQUESTS_IN is greater than one, the value is the estimated number of rows returned per input request.
Estimated cost associated with executing the current operator.
Estimated cost associated with execution of the current operator and all children.

Additional information about the operation. For example, in the case of a scan, the description field shows scan_type, scan_direction, lock_mode, access_mode, columns_retrieved, optimization information, and so on. For details about all operators and their description fields, see the Trafodion Query Guide.

section.para: This example uses OPTIONS 'n':Explain statement examples of

section.title: Expert User [OPTIONS 'e'] Considerations
section.para: The expert user optionExplain statement OPTIONS ’e’ considerations provides all the plan data OPTIONS on Explain statement ’e’from the EXPLAIN plan in a readable and understandable format. Like the normal user option, the expert user option provides a plan summary at the top of the output () and a node (or operator) listing. The difference between the normal user and expert user output is in the detail costs. The expert user option provides additional costing information and provides four digits of precision for all floating-point numbers.
Detail cost fields break down the EST_TOTAL_COST EST_TOTAL_COST fieldEXPLAIN output columnsEST_TOTAL_COST field into four components:

row.entry: Relative estimate of the processor cost needed to execute the instructions of this operator and all children.
Relative estimate of the I/O cost (depends on the number of seeks and amount of data transferred) needed to perform the I/O for this operator and all children.
Relative estimate of the messaging cost (depends on the number of local/remote messages and amount of data sent) for this operator and all children.
Relative estimate of the idle cost (depends on the amount of expected wait for an event) for this operator and all children. Events are opening a table, starting an ESP process, and so on.

section.para: This example uses OPTIONS ‘e’:Explain statement examples of

section.title: Machine-Readable [OPTIONS 'm'] Considerations
section.para: The machine-readable formatExplain statement OPTIONS ’m’ considerations also displays OPTIONS on Explain statement ’m’all of the plan data, but in a format easy to process by programs, one line per operator. This option provides the same output as the EXPLAIN function, but uses a different command to obtain the output. Each line is about 4000 characters long. This format makes the output of this mode difficult for humans to read (which is why it is called machine readable.) The advantage of this format is that the results can be easily stored, retrieved, and manipulated by SQL statements. For additional information about the EXPLAIN function, see the . For information about a use for this format, see the Trafodion Query Guide.
The fields of the OPTIONS ‘m’ output are slightly different than the fields shown in OPTIONS 'n' and 'e' output:

row.entry: Statement name; truncated on the right if longer than 60 characters.
Unique system-generated plan ID automatically assigned by SQL; generated at compile time.
Sequence number of the current operator in the operator tree; indicates the sequence in which the operator tree is generated.
Current operator type. For a full list of valid operator types, see the Trafodion Query Guide.
EXPLAIN output columns LEFT_CHILD_SEQ_ NUMLEFT_CHILD_ SEQ_NUM
Sequence number for the first child operator of the current operator; null if operator has no child operators.
EXPLAIN output columns RIGHT_CHILD_ SEQ_NUMRIGHT_CHILD_ SEQ_NUM
Sequence number for the second child operator of the current operator; null if operator does not have a second child.

For operators in scan group, full name of base table, truncated on the right if too long for column. If correlation name differs from table name, simple correlation name first and then table name in parentheses.

Estimated number of rows that are returned by the current operator. Cardinality appears as ROWS/REQUEST in some forms of EXPLAIN output. For the right child of a nested join, multiply the cardinality by the number of requests to get the total number of rows produced by this operator.
Estimated cost associated with the current operator to execute the operator.
Estimated cost associated with the current operator to execute the operator, including the cost of all subtrees in the operator tree.
Cost vector of five items, which are described in detail in the next table.
Additional information about the operator. For a detailed look at all operators, see the Trafodion Query Guide.

section.para: The DETAIL_COST column contains these cost factors:

row.entry: An estimate of the number of seconds of processor time it might take to execute the instructions for this operator. A value of 1.0 is 1 second.
An estimate of the number of seconds of I/O time (seeks plus data transfer) to perform the I/O for this operator.
An estimate of the number of seconds it takes for the messaging for this operator. The estimate includes the time for the number of local and remote messages and the amount of data sent.
An estimate of the number of seconds to wait for an event to happen. The estimate includes the amount of time to open a table or start an ESP process.
The number of times the operator will be executed. Usually, this value is 1, but it can be greater when you have, for example, an inner scan of a nested-loop join.

section.para: The following example has been edited to allow it to be displayed here (lines folded, trailing blanks removed, and so on).

section.title: Considerations for GET

important.para: The GET COMPONENT PRIVILEGES, GET COMPONENTS, GET ROLES FOR USER, and GET USERS FOR ROLE statements work only when authentication and authorization are enabled in Trafodion. For more information, see Enabling Security Features in the Trafodion wiki.

section.para: The GET statement displays delimited object names in their internal format. For example, the GET statement returns the delimited name "my ""table""" as my "table".

section.title: Required Privileges
section.para: To issue a GET statement, one of the following must be true:

listitem.para: You are DB__ROOT.
You have the SHOW component privilege for the SQL_OPERATIONS component. The SHOW component privilege is granted to PUBLIC by default.
This GET statement displays the names of all the schemas in the catalog of the current session, which happens to be the TRAFODION catalog:
listitem.programlisting: GET SCHEMAS;

listitem.programlisting: GET SCHEMAS IN CATALOG TRAFODION;

listitem.para: This GET statement displays the names of schemas owned by DB__ROOT:
listitem.programlisting: GET SCHEMAS FOR USER DB__ROOT;

listitem.para: This GET statement displays the names of all the tables in the catalog and schema of the current session, which happens to be TRAFODION.SEABASE:
listitem.programlisting: GET TABLES;

listitem.para: This GET statement displays the names of all the tables in the specified schema, SEABASE2, in the TRAFODION catalog:
listitem.programlisting: GET TABLES IN SCHEMA SEABASE2;

listitem.para: This GET statement displays the names of all the views in the catalog and schema of the current session, which happens to be TRAFODION.SEABASE:
listitem.programlisting: GET VIEWS;

listitem.para: This GET statement displays the names of all the views in the specified schema, SEABASE2, the TRAFODION catalog:
listitem.programlisting: GET VIEWS IN SCHEMA SEABASE2;

listitem.para: This GET statement displays the names of all the views that were created for the specified table, T, in the TRAFODION.SEABASE schema:

listitem.para: This GET statement displays the names of the libraries in the TRAFODION._MD_ schema:
listitem.programlisting: GET LIBRARIES IN SCHEMA "_MD_";

listitem.para: This GET statement displays the names of procedures registered in the library, TRAFODION._MD_.UDR_LIBRARY:

listitem.para: This GET statement displays the names of procedures in the TRAFODION._MD_ schema:
listitem.programlisting: GET PROCEDURES IN SCHEMA "_MD_";

listitem.para: This GET statement displays the names of procedures in the catalog and schema of the current session, which happens to be TRAFODION.SEABASE:
listitem.programlisting: GET PROCEDURES;

listitem.para: This GET statement displays the names of user-defined functions (UDFs) in the catalog and schema of the current session, which happens to be TRAFODION.SEABASE:

listitem.programlisting: get components;

listitem.para: This GET statement displays the names of the component privileges available for the SQL_OPERATIONS component:
listitem.programlisting: get component privileges on sql_operations;

listitem.para: This GET statement displays the component privileges that have been granted to the DB__ROOT user for the SQL_OPERATIONS component:

listitem.para: This GET statement displays a list of all the registered database users:

section.title: GRANT Statement
section.para: The GRANT statement grants access privileges on an SQL object to specified users or roles. The statement can specify either the object name or a synonym.

important.para: This statement works only when authentication and authorization are enabled in Trafodion. For more information, see Enabling Security Features in the Trafodion wiki.

entry.programlisting:
GRANT {privilege [,privilege]... |ALL [PRIVILEGES]} ON [object-type] [schema.]object TO {grantee [,grantee ]...} [WITH GRANT OPTION] [[GRANTED] BY grantor]
privilege is: SELECT [(column [,column]...)] | DELETE | INSERT [(column [,column]...)] | REFERENCES [(column [,column]...)] | UPDATE [(column [,column]...)] | EXECUTE | USAGE
object-type is: TABLE | PROCEDURE | LIBRARY | FUNCTION
grantee is: auth-name
grantor is: role-name

listitem.para: specifies the privileges to grant. You can specify these privileges for an object.

row.entry: Can create constraints that reference the object.
Can use the UPDATE statement on table objects.
Can execute a stored procedure using a CALL statement or can execute a user-defined function (UDF).
Can access a library using the CREATE PROCEDURE or CREATE FUNCTION statement. This privilege provides you with read access to the library’s underlying library file.

All the applicable privileges. When you specify ALL for a table or view, this includes the SELECT, DELETE, INSERT, REFERENCES, and UPDATE privileges. When the object is a stored procedure or user-defined function (UDF), only the EXECUTE privilege is applied. When the object is a library, only the UPDATE and USAGE privileges are applied.

listitem.para: names the columns of the object to which the SELECT, INSERT, UPDATE or REFERENCES privileges apply. If you specify these privileges without column names, the privileges apply to all columns of the table or view, now and in the future (if columns are added later).
specifies an object on which to grant privileges. object-type can be:
[TABLE] [schema.]object, where object is a table or view. See .
[PROCEDURE] [schema.]procedure-name, where procedure-name is the name of a stored procedure in Java (SPJ) registered in the database.
[LIBRARY] [schema.]library-name, where library-name is the name of a library object in the database.
[FUNCTION] [schema.]function-name, where function-name is the name of a user-defined function (UDF) in the database.
specifies one or more auth-names to which you grant privileges.

specifies the name of an authorization ID to which you grant privileges. See . The authorization ID must be a registered database username, an existing role name, or PUBLIC. The name is a regular or delimited case-insensitive identifier. See . If you grant a privilege to PUBLIC, the privilege remains available to all users, unless it is later revoked from PUBLIC.
specifies that the auth-name to which a privilege is granted may in turn grant the same privilege to other users or roles.
allows you to grant privileges on behalf of a role. If not specified, the privileges will be granted on your behalf as the current user/grantor.

specifies a role on whose behalf the GRANT operation is performed. To grant the privileges on behalf of a role, you must be a member of the role, and the role must have the authority to grant the privileges; that is, the role must have been granted the privileges WITH GRANT OPTION.

section.title: Authorization and Availability Requirements
section.para: To grant a privilege on an object, you must have both that privilege and the right to grant that privilege. Privileges can be granted directly to you or to one of the roles you have been granted. You can grant a privilege on an object if you are the owner of the object (by which you are implicitly granted all privileges on the object) or the owner of the schema containing the object, or if you have been granted both the privilege and the WITH GRANT OPTION for the privilege.

If granting privileges on behalf of a role, you must specify the role in the [GRANTED] BY clause. To grant the privileges on behalf of a role, you must be a member of the role, and the role must have the authority to grant the privileges; that is, the role must have been granted the privileges WITH GRANT OPTION.

If you lack authority to grant one or more of the specified privileges, SQL returns a warning (yet does grant the specified privileges for which you do have authority to grant). If you lack authority to grant any of the specified privileges, SQL returns an error.

listitem.para: To grant SELECT and DELETE privileges on a table to two specified users:
listitem.programlisting: GRANT SELECT, DELETE ON TABLE invent.partloc TO ajones, "MO.Neill@company.com";

listitem.para: To grant SELECT privileges on a table to a user:GRANT SELECT ON TABLE invent.partloc TO ajones;
To grant SELECT and DELETE privileges on a table to two specified users and allow these users to grant these privileges to other users:
listitem.programlisting: GRANT SELECT, DELETE ON TABLE invent.partloc TO ajones, "MO.Neill@company.com" WITH GRANT OPTION;

listitem.para: To grant SELECT privileges on a table to a user and a role:GRANT SELECT ON TABLE invent.partloc TO ajones, clerks;

To grant all privileges to a role on behalf of the table owner, JSMITH grants the SELECT privilege on the table to the role CLERKS. CMILLER, who has been granted the role CLERKS, grants the privilege to another user on behalf of the role: -- JSMITH: GRANT SELECT ON invent.partloc TO clerks WITH GRANT OPTION;
-- CMILLER: GRANT SELECT ON invent.partloc TO fred GRANTED BY clerks;

listitem.para: specifies a component name on which to grant component privileges. Currently, the only valid component name is SQL_OPERATIONS.
specifies an auth-name to which you grant component privileges.

specifies the name of an authorization ID to which you grant privileges. See . The authorization ID must be a registered database username, existing role name, or PUBLIC. The name is a regular or delimited case-insensitive identifier. See . If you grant a privilege to PUBLIC, the privilege remains available to all users, unless it is later revoked from PUBLIC.
specifies that the auth-name to which a component privilege is granted may in turn grant the same component privilege to other users or roles.
allows you to grant component privileges on behalf of a role. If not specified, the privileges will be granted on your behalf as the current user/grantor.
